Award.AwardTitle: Statistical and Applied Mathematical Sciences Institute
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
DMS 0635449
Principal Investigator: James O. Berger

SAMSI is a national institute that will deeply impact the future
of the statistical and mathematical sciences and, through them,
science in general, by catalyzing creation of the theory and
methodology necessary to confront the central data- and
model-driven scientific challenges of our time. SAMSI will focus
on new syntheses of the statistical sciences, applied mathematics
and disciplinary science. To illustrate the vision, consider an
activity central to modern science and technology, and with which
SAMSI will be heavily engaged: numerical modeling of complex
physical processes. Developing numerical models and evaluating
their fidelity to reality requires merging knowledge from
multiple disciplines. Applied mathematics builds on disciplinary
understanding to construct a fine-detail numerical representation
of the deterministic aspects of a process; probability provides
concepts and insight to characterize stochastic elements of the
process; and statistics provides the mechanisms to relate these
constructs to observational data on the real-world process. But,
despite a multiplicity of context-specific advances, there is
currently no general framework for combining these disciplines,
much less a formal system for simultaneously applying them. The
SAMSI efforts in this direction will focus on filling this gap,
by bringing together statisticians, mathematicians and modelers
from across the country (and beyond) to establish frameworks for
model development and validation, at a high level that spans
multiple application contexts.

To carry out this synthesis of the statistical sciences, applied
mathematical sciences and disciplinary sciences, SAMSI engages
established researchers - from academia, industry, national
laboratories and government - as well as young researchers
(postdoctoral fellows and graduate students) at the formative
stages of their careers. Each research program lasts from 6
months to one year, and involves a host of activities ranging
from research by intensive interdisciplinary working groups to
broad, energizing workshops. Outreach to undergraduate students,
high-school teachers and faculty from teaching institutions
extends SAMSI's impact on the essential development of the
national human resource base for science. To enable activities of
the breadth and depth necessary for the success of SAMSI, the
institute is a partnership between the National Science
Foundation and the consortium of Duke University, North Carolina
State University, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
and the National Institute of Statistical Sciences. These
partners provide a uniquely strong base for SAMSI's national
scope. Scientific input to SAMSI comes, in part, from a National
Advisory Council composed of eminent statistical and mathematical
scientists. Most important, SAMSI will engage the entire
nationwide statistical and mathematical sciences communities, by
means of widely publicized opportunities to bring problems to
SAMSI, or direct SAMSI's attention to them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Statistical and Applied Mathematical Sciences Institute (SAMSI) brings together statisticians, applied mathematicians and specialists in various scientific disciplines in fulfilment of its mission “to forge a synthesis of the statistical sciences and the applied mathematical sciences with disciplinary science to confront the very hardest and most important data- and model-driven scientific challenges.”

The primary activities are Research Programs that either last for a full academic year or for 1-3 weeks during the summer. SAMSI Research Programs include workshops, working groups to pursue research on a particular topic, and visitors. There is also a postdoc program (six postdocs newly appointed each year), and faculty and graduate fellows appointed by the three Triangle universities (Duke, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and North Carolina State University).

During 2007-12, SAMSI organized ten full-year research programs, listed in Table 1. In addition, there were four summer programs and a variety of activities of an educational or outreach nature.

Intellectual Merit

From its beginning, SAMSI has sought areas of research where statisticians and applied mathematicians can combine complementary skills to achieve results that neither group could do on its own. Most programs also develop interdisciplinary research with collaborators from a variety of fields.

As an example of how these objectives are achieved, we highlight the 2011-12 program on Uncertainty Quantification (UQ). This was SAMSI’s largest program ever and consisted of four components: Methodology, Climate Modeling, Engineering and Renewable Energy, and Geosciences. The impacts of the program included contributions to a new journal started in 2013 (Jim Berger, the first Director of SAMSI, was one of the founding co-editors) as well as a series of UQ conferences and new activity or interest groups in SIAM or ASA.

As an example of the research coming out of this program, a major goal of UQ is to understand the sensitivity of mathematical models that describe complex physical processes to changes in input parameters. This can be phrased as an inverse problem, to find the range of input parameters consistent with the uncertain output of a model. Program leader Don Estep and coauthors undertook a systematic study of this problem in a triad of papers. They describe the uncertainties in terms of probabilities, and use a measure-theoretic approach to design numerical methods for computing these probabilities. The third paper, published in the SIAM/ASA Journal on UQ, demonstrates the effectiveness of the measure-theoretic approach in an application with simulated noisy data from Hurricane Katrina. Estimating the amount of flooding in the wake of a hurricane and identifying safe passages for naval transportation requires knowledge of the ocean floor, specifically its depth and topography (bathymetry). A mathematical model was used to infer this information from noisy observations of the maximum storm surge. The success of the method was demonstrated through numerical experiments.

Another example of a SAMSI program that successfully brought together different disciplines is the program on Space-time Analysis for Environmental Mapping, Epidemiology and Climate Change (2009-10). IN a series of three papers, SAMSI postdoc Veronica Berrocal, with co-authors Alan Gelfand from Duke and David Holland from the Environmental Protection Agency, developed a Bayesian space-time downscaling fusion model approach to calculate predictive surfaces for air quality. Their method was incorporated into a model used by the Environmental Protection Agency, the Fused Air Quality Surface Using Downscaling (FAQSD) model, as part of its mandate to provide regularly updated reports on the nation’s air quality.

Table 1 gives a summary (based on program organizers’ reports) of papers, grant applications and software in all full-year programs during the project period; overall, some 286 papers, 15 grants and 11 software packages were directly attributed to SAMSI. Table 2 summarizes personnel who were long- or medium-term participants; they included senior and junior faculty visitors, faculty and graduate student fellows from the three sponsoring universities, visiting graduate students, and postdocs.

Broader Impacts

SAMSI programs play an educational and career development role at multiple levels. Table 3 shows the current employment status of all postdocs who entered SAMSI during the project period; 70% of them are currently in academic positions.

SAMSI organizes three workshops per year aimed at undergraduate students: a 2-day workshop each fall and spring and a week-long undergraduate modeling workshop in early summer. For graduate students, SAMSI organizes the Industrial Mathematical and Statistical Modeling workshop, a 10-day workshop each summer where students work on projects suggested by industry or government researchers. Reviews from participants in these workshops have repeatedly affirmed their value in introducing students to research.

 SAMSI has shown a consistent track record in working to support diversity and encourage the involvement of underrepresented groups in its activities. Figure 1 shows how the percentages of women and ethnic minorities have varied over the years.
